metadata.case_name: Employees (Appellants) v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.

facts.text: Presidential Order dated 18th October, 1975 issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution aimed at providing equitable opportunities in public employment.

GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 made UDCs in Labour Department and Factories and Boilers Department eligible for recruitment by transfer to Assistant Inspectors of Labour and Factories.
Full Bench of Tribunal declared impugned rules violative of paras 3 and 5 of Presidential Order.
In V. Jagannadha Rao v. State of AP, 2001 10 SCC 401, Supreme Court held rules violative of Presidential Order, overruled Sadanandam and Satyanarayana Rao cases, pronounced on 7th November, 2001.

G.O.M. No.14 dated 26th November, 1994 (Labour Employment Training Ser. IV Department), amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996, provided Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers in Head Offices and Factories/Boilers eligible for appointment by transfer to Assistant Labour Officer (zonal post).
Employees approached Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997 challenging GOMs as violative of Presidential Order paras 3(3) and 5(1).

Tribunal order dated 7th March, 2003 partly allowed petitions, struck down GOMs to extent providing channel from outside zone, directed no effect to provisions, but prospective overruling - actions till 7th November, 2001 not disturbed, no reversion.
Writ Petitions No.6163, 6068 of 2004 filed challenging Tribunal's prospective saving; WP No.16890 of 2006 challenging striking down.
High Court order dated 9th March, 2007 allowed WPs 6163/6068, dismissed 16890/2006, set aside Tribunal's prospective application, held doctrine invocable only by Supreme Court.
Review petition WPMP No.3576 of 2010 filed by appellants (promoted employees not impleaded), dismissed on 3rd November, 2010.
Promoted employees held positions for nearly ten years till review dismissal.
State declined to create supernumerary posts per affidavit by Commissioner of Labour.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in setting aside the Tribunal's application of prospective overruling to save promotions made under GOMs violative of Presidential Order.
Whether Supreme Court should invoke doctrine of prospective overruling to protect past promotions given law was in flux, parties not impleaded, and reversion would be harsh.

petitioner_arguments.text: Promoted employees (appellants) were necessary parties not impleaded in Tribunal or High Court proceedings, hence challenges to rules should be dismissed.
Doctrine of prospective overruling applicable as law in flux till Jagannadha Rao (2001), promotions made on valid prevailing rules, reversion harsh after long service.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Doctrine of prospective overruling; Kailash Chand Sharma v. State of Rajasthan

respondent_arguments.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling invocable only by Supreme Court, not Tribunal or High Court.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Golak Nath v. State of Punjab; decisions limiting to Apex Court

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioners took calculated risk opting for out-of-zone promotions.

court_reasoning.text: Explained origin and parameters of doctrine of prospective overruling from Golak Nath, applicable only by Supreme Court under Constitution matters, moulds relief for justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Doctrine evolved in US, cautiously applied in India, parameters: only Constitution matters, only by SC, retroactivity at SC discretion.

court_reasoning.text: Cited cases where SC applied prospectively even for first time determinations (India Cement, Orissa Cement, Ramzan Khan), upheld under Art 142 for complete justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art 142 enables moulding relief, prospective overruling recognizes equity, not impotent to adjust rights.

court_reasoning.text: In Kailash Chand, applied prospectively due to law flux, non-impleadment of appointees; similar here - law flux till 2001, promoted not parties, long tenure, reversion cascadingly prejudicial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No risk as promotions by State on prevailing valid rules; Jagannadha Rao different GOMs.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to decide if High Court could invoke; SC can invoke to prevent injustice, save pre-7 Nov 2001 promotions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State unwilling for supernumerary posts, reversion unfair after promotions to higher posts.

holdings.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling invoked to save promotions made before 7th November, 2001 under impugned GOMs; no disturbance or reversion.
High Court judgment set aside to extent it declared past actions unconstitutional without prospective application.

precedents_cited.case_name: V. Jagannadha Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Held transfer rules violative of Presidential Order; date 7.11.2001 key for prospective cut-off.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. V. Sadanandam
precedents_cited.relevance: Earlier upheld similar transfers; overruled in Jagannadha Rao.

precedents_cited.case_name: Govt. of A.P. v. B. Satyanarayana Rao
precedents_cited.relevance: Earlier upheld similar transfers; overruled in Jagannadha Rao.
Statute read as whole, intention from language said and unsaid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Institute of Chartered Accountants of India v. Price Waterhouse
Golak Nath v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: First invoked prospective overruling in India, laid parameters.

precedents_cited.case_name: India Cement Ltd. v. State of Tamil Nadu
precedents_cited.relevance: Prospective declaration of invalidity, no refund.

precedents_cited.case_name: Orissa Cement Ltd. v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction invalidity vs relief; mould relief for justice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Mohd. Ramzan Khan
Ashok Kumar Gupta v. State of U.P.
Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
precedents_cited.relevance: Overruled Golak Nath on amendability but upheld prospective.

precedents_cited.case_name: M/s Somaiya Organics (India) Ltd. v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Prospective as moulding relief under Art 142 for equity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kailash Chand Sharma v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Applied prospective due to flux, non-impleadment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Managing Director, ECIL Hyderabad v. B. Karunakar

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Proviso Art 309 rules subordinate to Presidential Order under Art 371D(10); Art 142 for complete justice and prospective overruling.

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Pradesh Public Employment (Organisation of Local Cadres and Regulation of Direct Recruitment) Order, 1975
statutes_cited.relevance: Local cadre unit for recruitment/promotion/transfer; limits on transfer excluding promotion; violated by GOMs allowing cross-zone transfers.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed appeals, invoked doctrine of prospective overruling to protect promotions made before 7th November 2001 under invalid GOMs, set aside High Court order to that extent, prevented reversion as harsh and unjust given circumstances.
outcome.relief_granted: Past promotions saved prospectively; no reversion or disturbance.

key_quotes.text: "The doctrine of prospective overruling can be invoked only in matters arising under our Constitution... only by the highest court of the country, i.e., the Supreme Court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Parameters from Golak Nath defining SC exclusivity.

key_quotes.text: "Prospective overruling, despite the terminology, is only a recognition of the principle that the court moulds the reliefs claimed to meet the justice of the case - justice not in its logical but in its equitable sense."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Essence of doctrine for equity under Art 142.

key_quotes.text: "Reversion of the petitioners to their parent cadre is therefore bound to have a cascading effect, prejudicing even those who are not parties before us."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for applying prospective to avoid broader injustice.
